text: hi this is Katherine from Lang Today
we'll show you how you can run an
evaluation in Linksmith in the UI From
creating a data set to finding
evaluators to running an experiment
roles like product managers or subject
matter experts typically have the most
context on the quality and performance
of an LM application Thus they can play
a crucial role in leading the evaluation
and improving AI applications
For today's demo let's imagine that
we're building a legal research agent
for lawyers This agent summarizes legal
case opinions helping lawyers quickly
assess case relevance and understand
judicial opinions There are a few steps
to running an offline evaluation
linksmith First we want to decide on the
application logic or in this case the
prompt that we want to test over Next we
want to create a ground truth data set
with inputs and reference outputs It's
important to run an experiment against a
set of represented examples This helps
ensure predictable performance over the
common use cases of your
application Third we need to define the
metrics we'll use to evaluate
performance These are quality evaluators
that reflect the key aspects of the
output that we care about And finally
after running the evaluation we'll have
experiment results that implies the
performance of our application I can
then go iterate on my prompt and
continue to test it against the same
data set to ensure that these metrics
improve over time And now let's hop over
to LinkSmith to show how a LinkSmith
user like product manager or legal
council in this case can walk through
the evaluation flow in the
UI Now we're in the playground view in
Linksmith Playground provides an
environment where you can rapidly
iterate test and experiment with
different prompts
Let's create the legal prompt from
scratch So first we'll assign a persona
You're a expert legal researcher that is
dedicated to writing briefs Please
ground your response in a provided
context and be concise in your response
So next I'll give it a set of
instructions and below I'll paste in the
typical components and definitions of a
legal case brief
So this includes components such as
heading facts procedural history issues
holding rule and reasoning So now that
we have a first version of our prompt we
can save it as a reusable asset to be
iterated on in the prompt Let's call
this legal case
brief And clicking on this popped up
message this takes us to the prompt
which also tracks the commit versions
and histories
So now pulling this back into the
playground we're now ready for step two
of the evaluation flow creating a data
set So clicking on the button on the top
right This first prompts you to select
from an existing data set I can also
create a new data set in line Since the
purpose of our prompt is to generate
case briefs for our data set we want a
list of examples of case opinions and
reference briefs So here in the case
input I'll add in the lengthy case
opinions and as a reference output I'll
paste in the example briefs Click add
roll Great So now we have a data set
ready with five examples We can save the
data set Give it a
name Now with a data set and prompt to
test out we're ready to set up
evaluation For a legal brief use case
there are several metrics that I likely
care about One is hallucination We want
to check our answers to be grounded on
the facts This is important especially
for sensitive use cases like legal to
remain factually accurate The second is
correctness We want to check if our
output semantically match our reference
responses The third is conciseness
Because this is a brief after all we
want the prompt to be readable and
concise while capturing the essence of
the case And finally a good brief will
have all the sections that I have
outlined in a prompt So we will likely
want to check if all the required
sections of my brief are being
generated Several of these evaluators
are fairly common use cases and have
already been built out of the box for me
So for the first evaluator
correctness we can inspect the prompt
together This is a prompt that gives a
role for LM judge provides a set of
rubrics and instructions At the bottom
of the prompt it maps our inputs and
checks our output against the reference
one The prompt defaults to general input
but based on the context given on the
right hand side we can more specifically
map it to the key that we want to test
on In our case this would be input
question and we can see it being
highlighted on the right hand side And
similarly for reference output it's
reference output dot
output And then for output it's
output.output.content We can hit save
here And this is being added as
evaluator For the second evaluator we'll
choose the hallucination one Similarly
it gives it a role a set of rubrics and
instructions
The hallucination evaluator checks our
outputs against econtext which in this
case is also our input Similarly we'll
map both to the input
question For the third evaluator the
conciseness one if we scroll down we can
see that this directly checks the output
based on its consision We also map this
to the relevant key in the data
format and we can hit
save Finally to create my own evaluator
I'll click on elements a judge here can
see the correctness judge template
popped up So for this evaluator we will
want to evaluate based on
completeness We'll also modify the
prompt below can say you're an expert
data labeler evaluating model outputs
for completeness For a rubric a correct
answer should have all of the sections
that we have provided in the prompt So a
correct answer should have all of the
following sections So that includes
facts procedural history issues holding
rule and reasoning And for instructions
we'll say when scoring you should
penalize incomplete or missing sections
And for the remainder of the prompt
we'll change all the correctness to
completeness Similarly now I'll map the
keys to a data structure input
Output.output.content as well as
reference
output.output And rather than giving a
boolean value we'll do a score between 1
and 10 because there are multiple
sections that we're checking on Now I
hit create And this evaluator is added
From here I can hit start This will
start populating first the generated
outputs from a prompt based on the
inputs When that's done it will run
evaluators that judges the outputs based
on the inputs Looks like our evaluators
has finished running We can view all the
scores in this playground view I can
also directly click this button for full
experiment This will open up the
experiment page for me I can side by
side inspect reference output versus our
generated output I can also scroll
through to see our evaluator
scores Click it into any of the
evaluator run If we scroll through to
the LM output this allows to inspect the
decision- making process for our LM as a
judge and we can further annotate this
evaluator run with additional human
feedback Clicking on the data set it
will bring us to the overall experiment
view The experiment view allows me to
view aggregated results across
experiment runs Here I only ran one
experiment but I can see that overall my
prompt did not produce any hallucinator
results scored well in completeness but
has room to improve in terms of
conciseness and correctness Now having
this information I can then go iterate
on my prompt and continue to test it
against the same data set to ensure that
these metrics improve over time
